content: The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 may be cited as the temporary suspension of motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007, also known as the temporary suspension of motor fuel taxes, includes a provision to temporarily suspend taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene. This amendment adds a new subsection to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, stating that during the suspension period, the rates of tax on these fuels will be reduced to zero. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends retail taxes on diesel fuel, special motor fuels, compressed natural gas, additional taxes for the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund, certain alcohol fuels, and Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund tax. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends retail taxes on diesel fuel, special motor fuels, compressed natural gas, certain alcohol fuels, and Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund tax. Exceptions include fuel used in trains or motorboats, and gasoline or kerosene used for aviation. The suspension period is from the enactment of the subsection until the end date. The suspension period defined as starting from the enactment of the subsection until the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is less than $3.00 per gallon. Trust fund deposits will be maintained by appropriating an amount equal to the revenue reduction due to any rate reduction under this subsection. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. Repeal of expensing for certain refineries. Repeal of Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, along with technical amendments to various sections of the Code. The repeal of section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is accompanied by technical amendments to related sections, including the transfer of equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund. The repeal of section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involves transferring appropriated amounts to the Highway Trust Fund based on estimated tax liabilities, with adjustments made for prior estimates. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Before the enactment of this Act, if a tax was imposed on liquid held by a dealer for sale, a credit or refund will be given to the taxpayer for the excess amount paid. No credit or refund will be allowed after a certain time for filing claims. The Act allows taxpayers to claim a credit or refund for excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the enactment date. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with dealers required to submit refund requests to taxpayers within 3 months. The Act allows taxpayers to claim a credit or refund for excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the enactment date. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with dealers required to submit refund requests to taxpayers within 3 months. No credit or refund is allowed for liquid in retail stocks intended for retail sale. Definitions for this section are provided. No credit or refund is allowed for liquid in retail stocks intended for retail sale. Definitions for this section are provided, including the terms "dealer" and "held by a dealer" as defined in section 6412 of the Code. Rules similar to those in section 6412 apply for this section. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed if the taxable event occurred on that date over the tax already paid. Liability for Tax: The person holding the liquid on the floor stocks tax date is responsible for paying the tax. Liability for tax is imposed on a person holding a liquid on the floor stocks tax date. The tax must be paid as prescribed by the Secretary and within 6 months of the tax date. A liquid is considered "held by a person" if title has passed to that person. Definitions for this section include the terms "held by a person" meaning title has passed to the person, "taxable liquid" subject to a specific tax, "floor stocks tax date" as the day after the suspension period, and "Secretary" referring to the Secretary of the relevant Code. The tax imposed by subsection (a) does not apply to taxable liquid held for exempt uses or in the tank of a motor vehicle or motorboat. The term "date" refers to the first day after the suspension period, and "Secretary" means the Secretary of the Treasury or delegate. No tax is imposed on taxable liquid held in a vehicle tank or for certain amounts of liquid held by a person not exceeding 2,000 gallons on the floor stocks tax date. Exempt fuel is not included in the tax calculation for liquid held by any person exempt from the tax. Controlled groups are treated as one person for tax purposes. Controlled groups are treated as one person for tax purposes, with the definition of a controlled group being based on ownership of more than 50 percent instead of at least 80 percent. Nonincorporated persons under common control are also subject to regulations prescribed by the Secretary. Under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, principles similar to those for controlled groups apply to nonincorporated persons under common control where one or more of them is not a corporation. Other laws applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 of the Code also apply to the floor. The floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) are subject to the same rules as taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 of the Code. Gasoline price monitoring is addressed in Section 6. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline monthly. Reports on monitoring results will be submitted to Congress by the 15th day of each month. The Federal Trade Commission will transmit a report to Congress each month containing the results of monitoring gasoline prices, as well as making the report available to the public online. SEC. 7. COMMISSION ON GAS PRICE RELIEF. Establishment of a Commission on Gas Price Relief by the Speaker of the House of Representatives within three months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will study the causes of high oil prices and submit a report to the House within a year. The report will include revenue raisers to replenish the Treasury after any suspension of Federal excise taxes on motor fuels. The Commission on Gas Price Relief will study high oil prices and propose revenue raisers to replenish the Treasury after suspending Federal excise taxes on motor fuels. It will consist of 9 Members, including the Chairmen of the Committees on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce. The Commission on Gas Price Relief will consist of 9 Members, including the Chairmen of the Committees on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce, who will serve as co-chairmen. Other members will be appointed by the Speaker and the Chairmen, with restrictions on political party affiliations.
